story:
The 2 Films

Farm

Background

Shootstraight is a project directed by film maker Lucinda Cary that engages young people who are growing up in local authority care, who have been excluded from school or who are in the criminal justice system, in screen acting workshops that lead to the production and screening of short films drawn from their own improvisations and stories.

It's a constant revelation, both the empowering potential of the creative process in these young peoples’ lives and the intensity of the performances that they deliver on screen.

NEW CROSS GATE trailer

3 years of shootstraight has led to the emergence of a company of 6 formidable actors who have shown immense reserves of inventiveness and resilience in the face of their complicated lives and who are determined to continue their involvement with performance and film. FARM is a section of a feature length script that Lucinda has written for them. 


Synopsis

Farm tells the story of Tariq, a young Londoner on Tottenham’s notorious ‘Farm’ Estate, facing the challenges of moving on from a difficult past. Tariq is torn between conflicting loyalties to his new girlfriend, Sophie and her aspirations for change, and his oldest friend Kameo. Tariq finds himself implicated in an armed robbery committed by Kameo, and in an effort to make it all go away he trades invented information with police about his erstwhile friend Mo being radicalised, when in fact Mo is at home studying and taking care of his 16 year old sister. It is an act of betrayal that will force him to reevaluate his life, his friendships, and his future.


The Cast

Abdullah Alhalaki
Fayzah Chaaban
Sapphire Collu
Aimie Gilmour
Kamarl Glanville

Nocir Tariq Moulay


Meet The Cast

Cast photographs taken by Katie Wilson on location at Broadwater Farm.


Location

Broadwater Farm Estate, Tottenham, London
Known locally as ‘Farm’, the estate was built as a 1960s experiment in high density housing, it is famous for being the starting point of the 1985 and 2011 riots. It is one of the most ethnically diverse locations in London; in 2005 its official population of 3,800 included residents of 39 different nationalities. 


Abdullah


The Story

Abdullah Alhalaki doesn't know who he is. Not really. Born in Yemen in 1994, he thinks, to a Somalian father and a Yemeni mother during the Somalian civil war, his father was murdered while his mother was pregnant, and his mother disappeared the day he was born. Neighbours heard a baby crying, and so began life for Abdullah.

He was brought to Tottenham, London, via Delhi and Manchester, by a paternal aunt and her husband, who pretended, even to him, that he was one of their own children. He was treated differently to his two brothers, until Social Services became interested when Abdullah started showing up to school with signs of physical abuse. Panicking, his aunt took him back to Yemen, where she left him, taking his passport with her.

Staying with relatives and with an immature camel as his closest companion, Abdullah noticed a tearful old woman watching him from a distance, when he approached her she revealed that she was in fact his maternal grandmother, that his mother’s whereabouts were unknown, and that who he thought was his mother was his dead father’s sister.

Abdullah’s older brother-cousin helped him, through the British embassy, to get back to London, where he was sent to stay with his father’s brother, until, protecting his pregnant uncle’s wife from his uncle’s rage got him a serious beating, and at 14 he became homeless, escaping from foster placements and living rough with other homeless boys. The boys slept in piles for warmth, ‘like puppies’.

Abdullah earned himself a six months stay in Feltham Young Offenders Institute for his involvement in the 2011 riots, and in 2013, amidst further petty convictions and gang trouble, he found his way onto a performing arts Btech, his comedic performance talent got him noticed and he was invited to take part in a screen acting workshop run by Shootstraight at Goldsmiths University, becoming part of a company of actors for whom the short film Farm was written, now in preproduction and scheduled to shoot this September.

Abdullah is now juggling motorbike deliveries with a Theatre and Politics course at the Royal Court Theatre and preparing Shakespeare monologues for his upcoming audition at RADA.

Abdullah has a thousand questions about where he has come from, why the truth has been hidden from him, and above all, where and who is his mother?

The documentary will see Abdullah follow the clues, and despite the lack of an airport (it was bombed out of use by the Saudi coalition in 2015), returning to Yemen to find his mother. He will start by finding his camel... 


Making the 2 films happen

We are really inspired by these two projects and are committed to completing them no matter what. Shootstraight was lucky enough to be given 2 Cameras by Black Magic Design, which we will be using for both projects.  We need lenses, and some other kit but we are off to a good start.

We have a really fabulous crew who are ready to start on both projects this September, and are willing to work for a lot less than their daily rates, and with a heartfelt commitment to the projects that money could not buy!

FARM will be shot in a maximum of 4 days and we have worked out that the entire project right through to completion could be done for £12500, if everyone is willing to work at London living wage and bring their own sandwiches! 

We aim to finish shooting ABDULLAH by next spring, there are so many variables involved, because we really don't know where the search will take us,  but that is all part of the excitement of this mysterious project. We believe that £12500, and the cameras we already have, will get us well on our way.

These projects have come out of Shootstraight which has up to now been a community project with a huge amount of heart. Our events are always emotional and our loyal friends and supporters love us and have become part of the Shootstraight family. By helping us make these two films you too will become part of the Shootstraight family. We really look forward to sharing our progress with you and seeing you there when we finally come to our red carpet premieres!

The success of FARM on the festival success will represent one complete revolution of the Shootstraight wheel. The young people involved will have been through the long process that saw them initially engage with what must have been a very alien and challenging forum where they dared to give their imaginations expression and will now see each of them launched onto their own exciting professional journeys. FARM can then act as the calling card for developing the full length feature film of which it is a section.


Challenges

It will be a new experience for all of us, after 3 years of making films out of improvised drama and without a crew, to work with a script and a crew, and all that that entails, but it is the obvious next step for us. It is the bridge to making the feature film that we believe in. We have some wonderful help at hand, like Charles Steel, Bafta winning producer of 'The Last King of Scotland' and 'Top Boy', who has been acting as executive producer, and giving us invaluable help, advice and support. We are determined to learn as we go, and deliver something really fresh and exciting that will defy all expectations.

The making of ABDULLAH is likely to present us with all sorts of unseen challenges as we go along, because of the nature of the story that we will be uncovering, but I have every confidence in our team, and in Abdullah himself. It's an important story for so many reasons and we are determined to find a way to tell it. 


How you can help us

There are many ways you can help us. You can help us raise the budget, even a donation of £1 gets us a little closer to our goal. If you can't help with funding but you have been moved by our story, and our company of young actors, you can help us by telling other people, tell your friends and relations and networks, a simple share can really help! 
Thank you.

Links

www.shootstraight.co.uk
To 'n' Fro is our website that will follow the making of both films right the way through to completion. 
 http://scary2.wixsite.com/carycary

trouble, he found his way onto a performing arts Btech, his comedic performance talent
got him noticed and he was invited to take part in a screen acting workshop run by
Shootstraight at Goldsmiths University, becoming part of a company of actors for whom
the short film Farm was written, now in preproduction and scheduled to shoot this
September.

Abdullah is now juggling motorbike deliveries with a Theatre and Politics course at the
Royal Court Theatre and preparing Shakespeare monologues for his upcoming audition at
RADA.

Abdullah has a thousand questions about where he has come from, why the truth has
been hidden from him, and above all, where and who is his mother?

The documentary will see Abdullah follow the clues, and despite the lack of an airport (it
was bombed out of use by the Saudi coalition in 2015), returning to Yemen to find his
mother. He will start by finding his camel... 







Making the 2 films happen
We are really inspired by these two projects and are committed to completing them no matter what. Shootstraight was lucky enough to be given 2 Cameras by Black Magic Design, which we will be using for both projects.  We need lenses, and some other kit but we are off to a good start.


We have a really fabulous crew who are ready to start on both projects this September, and are willing to work for a lot less than their daily rates, and with a heartfelt commitment to the projects that money could not buy!
FARM will be shot in a maximum of 4 days and we have worked out that the entire project right through to completion could be done for £12500, if everyone is willing to work at London living wage and bring their own sandwiches! 
We aim to finish shooting ABDULLAH by next spring, there are so many variables involved, because we really don't know where the search will take us,  but that is all part of the excitement of this mysterious project. We believe that £12500, and the cameras we already have, will get us well on our way.
These projects have come out of Shootstraight which has up to now been a community project with a huge amount of heart. Our events are always emotional and our loyal friends and supporters love us and have become part of the Shootstraight family. By helping us make these two films you too will become part of the Shootstraight family. We really look forward to sharing our progress with you and seeing you there when we finally come to our red carpet premieres!
The success of FARM on the festival success will represent one complete revolution of the Shootstraight wheel.
The young people involved will have been through the long process that saw them
initially engage with what must have been a very alien and challenging forum where
they dared to give their imaginations expression and will now see each of them launched
onto their own exciting professional journeys. FARM can then act as the calling card for developing the full length feature film of which it is a
section.










Challenges
It will be a new experience for all of us, after 3 years of making films out of improvised drama and without a crew, to work with a script and a crew, and all that that entails, but it is the obvious next step for us. It is the bridge to making the feature film that we believe in. We have some wonderful help at hand, like Charles Steel, Bafta winning producer of 'The Last King of Scotland' and 'Top Boy', who has been acting as executive producer, and giving us invaluable help, advice and support. We are determined to learn as we go, and deliver something really fresh and exciting that will defy all expectations.
The making of ABDULLAH is likely to present us with all sorts of unseen challenges as we go along, because of the nature of the story that we will be uncovering, but I have every confidence in our team, and in Abdullah himself. It's an important story for so many reasons and we are determined to find a way to tell it. 
How you can help usThere are many ways you can help us. You can help us raise the budget, even a donation of £1 gets us a little closer to our goal. If you can't help with funding but you have been moved by our story, and our company of young actors, you can help us by telling other people, tell your friends and relations and networks, a simple share can really help! Thank you.Links
www.shootstraight.co.uk

To 'n' Fro is our website that will follow the making of both films right the way through to completion. 
 http://scary2.wixsite.com/carycary

story:
Do you love the 90s? Yeah – so do I.

My name is Ryan Casey – I’m the writer and director of Gener’s People – a TV show pilot that is set in the 90’s.

I have spent my life writing fiction and bringing it to the screen.  Recently I took a hiatus from filmmaking and attained my Master’s in Communication from the University of Hartford.

This past year – while talking to cinematographer, David Sikora – I mentioned my idea for Gener’s People and didn’t think much of it – just a passing conversation.  The next day Dave was at my doorstep demanding to shoot this.  He thought it was the most original and powerful original story he had ever heard.

Since then – We have shot a short version (which you should watch on this page ...Right now!) and now we need your help to fund a full pilot episode.

Everyone – both cast and crew – worked and sweated hard for free for the shorter version.  I poured my own money into the short and paid for everything we needed.  But we all have rent to pay and need some more funds to pay for more crew, cast, and bigger locations.

Take a look at the short sample we did to see the quality we are bringing to the screen.

The story of Gener’s People is also something you will help bring to life.  It’s all set in the 90’s.  My favorite decade--it was an era of jeans, the birth and death of grunge, and going to Blockbuster on a Friday night. 

Gener's People is about a juice-bar and the struggles it takes to get off the ground.  It’s a time when WholeFoods, Trader Joe’s and Sprouts are just getting off the ground.  The word "organic" was thought to be a paper-folding method.  We’re going to cover and explore that cultural paradigm shift – in a fictional world!  And there’s major twist to our story – some people have started to overindulge in the juice.  But I can’t go into more detail than that.  Because yeah, it’s a spoiler.

This talented independent cast and crew of struggling artists could use your help. 

We have collected some of the best performers in the northeast – pouring over 1,000 applications to act in our project.  We have collected some of the best film production craftspeople in the northeast.  Please help them complete their mission of making a show that will break many boundaries and fill you with exhilaration and awe.

And check-out my personal track-record to lead this team – I have completed numerous shorts as well as a feature-length film (1 hr. 40 min,) called American Jubilee.  All have been completely finished and shown at film festivals.  Many projects don’t get past the shooting stage – but I get things done.  I’m a persistent Irish Jew. 

Yeah I just wrote that. 

Please help Gener’s People come alive to the screen by donating today.  And if you donate you will get a gift.  We will also give you the opportunity to be an extra during one day of our next shooting!

Be part of the magic here.

Also please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.  You can do this by using the Indiegogo share tools on this web page!

story:
Story

Black Retina tells the story of Lucas, a man who possesses a very rare and special ability. He can enter a person's mind and read their memories. This gift, however, comes with a price. See, for every mind he enters, he inherits that character's personality. So what happens when Lucas' mind is overwhelmed by so many personas? Eventually, one will take over...but which one?

Pilot Episode

After failing to protect the son of a cartel boss, Jamie turns to his brother Lucas for help, who has the unique ability of entering a person's mind and reading their memories.

Juan Herrera - Producer/Director

A Texas boy based in the bay area, Juan has been a filmmaker for over 7 years. He has written numerous projects ranging from screenplays to short stories, to training videos. Most of the stories he's written is in the thriller/drama genre. Recently, he's wrapped up post-production work on an independent feature "Railway Spine", and is currently developing the story on another. Black Retina is his first narrative series in the works! Working alongside his partner in crime and co-producer, his wife :), his goal is to deliver an exciting and captivating story.

Budget

Crew/Production: 60%

Food: 20%

Props/Equipment: 10%

Transportation: 10%

story:
Story


A tragic romantic drama with elements of comedy, Siren follows a young man named Eric who is struggling to get over the death of his partner, Jess. Taking to an addictive substance that allows the user to be reconnected with their dead loved ones, he spends a last night alone with her - over and over again. 

Who we are

We are a group of enthusiastic student filmmakers currently studying film and television production in Auckland, New Zealand. After working together numerous times throughout the last few years, we've built up a  passion to constantly improve and go further and further with our projects, which has led to the creation of our most ambitious project yet...

However, we need your help. As you know, making films is an expensive endeavor with lots of hidden costs. In order to create a final product that we (and you!) can be proud of is going to cost money, and that's why we're turning to you... to be a part of the journey and the exhilarating process that is film making. 


Crew

Logan Marshall
Writer/ Director

Logan Marshall is a passionate young filmmaker currently studying Drama Directing and Production Management at South Seas Film & Television School. Filled with a burning desire to create films from a young age, he has worked tirelessly to make this dream become a reality. Originally pulling friends and family along to help star/ crew on his projects, he has since networked together a group of like-minded creatives that have worked together to create numerous short films and music videos. His love for the art of cinema and passion for creating compelling narratives is what has led to his desire to create "Siren."


Jacky Tan
Cinematographer


Jacky Tan is a passionate and aspiring Cinematographer from Malaysia currently completing his pursue of the course Camera, Lighting & Audio in South Seas Film & TV School. Before pursuing this course, he has already built a wide range of film portfolio back in Malaysia and Singapore, winning local school film awards, having his work shown during film festival in cinemas, and also started freelance filming on the side, which in turn unexpectedly helped him gained many clients. He has since been working alongside Logan Marshall in various exciting projects in school and also outside of school environment. His interests lies among creating extraordinary and beautiful images, and also utilizing visuals for storytelling.


Brianna Cox
Producer

21-year-old Brie moved to Auckland from Wellington to pursue her passion for acting. After studying at South Seas Film & Television School and then at The Actor’s Program, she discovered an enjoyment and flair in production management. Currently in her final months of studying production at South Seas, she plans to work as both an actor and in a production company next year. As an actor, producer and an all-round film-maker, Brie strives to bring stories to life from a script to the screen, whether it be in front of or behind the camera. 


Cast

Zach Douglas
'Eric'

Coming off the back of a lead role in an indie feature, Zach Douglas is an impassioned, wholehearted young actor who is ready to take on interesting and exciting roles. He performs with drive and a sincerity to not only portray a character, but to bring them to life in a way that resounds with an audience; which is why he is perfect for the role of Eric. 

Jzayla Hughey
'Jess'

Jzayla Hughey, 20, is a talented up-and-coming Australian actress that has been involved in musicals, modelling and theater productions internationally. Currently studying On-Screen Acting at South Seas Film & Television School in Auckland, she commits fully towards the preparation of any role in order to bring believably and truth to every character.


What we've done

As a crew we've worked together numerous times on a variety of different projects (for our own amusement and for clients), which has led to a strong working relationship between the team and a constant desire to improve from project-to-project. Here's a link to our most recent (released) music video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SK-n0dcHYRk

Also, here's some production photos from Behind the Scenes on a (currently top-secret) project that we finished shooting a couple of weeks ago!

Interested in more Behind the Scenes content of our various shoots? Click here: https://www.instagram.com/loganmarshall99/


What we need

  • Funding. We're diving head-first in to production mid-October, and we've estimated that we need to raise $2000 in order to (just) comfortably fund the project. 
  • Where will the money go? All proceeds will do directly to the production of this film. This includes covering the cost of: location hire-age (35%), wardrobe/ set-dressing (21%), lighting the final scene (15%), wireless follow focus (for 2 days, 19%), and Catering (10%).
  • What happens if we don't reach our goal? Although challenging, our crew has a knack for creating high-production value from shoe-string budgets. We may have to drop some of our grander ideas/ locations, but we believe that we can still create an engaging short film with limited money. 
  • But what if we EXCEED our goal? Perfect! This would give us more room to add higher production value to the film, and work in a few of the more expensive/ elaborate ideas that we think would help bring this film to the next level. It would also give us a bit more in the pocket to cover festival submissions.

Perks

We've put together a bunch of wicked (and cost-efficient!) perks for those that decide to support us in bringing this film to life. See right column for details!

 

Impact

After completing our film, we plan on submitting it to festivals nationally and internationally (with an emphasis on the latter). There are thousands of short film competitions around the world, and with your support we have no doubt that our film will find an audience in many of them!

Challenges
Our largest challenge is that we're trying to create something that is quite ambitious for the budget (even if we can reach our goal of $2000), that is also new and exciting (for us). We don't have a lot of experience in the type of film that we are trying to create (an intimate, character-driven piece between only two characters), but we're confident that we've got the right people to combat this risk with their skills. We have two very talented actors who we believe can convey the weight and emotions of the film through their performance, and a dedicated crew who we know will support them - and bring their own sets of skills to the table.  

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand and appreciate the fact that not everyone has the spare cash to donate to our cause. However, you can still be a part of bringing this project to life!

By following and sharing our IndieGoGo page, you help us to get more eyes on the project - which means more people that are likely to help support us in our endeavors, and you become a part of the process. For this we would be eternally grateful! 

Thank you.

Thank you.

story:
WE ECHO TO BOOM

We chose our name to honor our history. We are an "ECHO" of the days when Tuskegee thrived. Connecting the past and present, we added "boom" since our platform is a place where conversations explode. 

ECHOboom is a multi-media platform featuring blogs, news, opinions, videos, community calendar, community business directory, tourism resources, Tuskegee University student innovators, alumni success stories and a university marketplace populated by student and alumni business enterprises. ECHboom is accessible 24/7 on your smart phone, iPad and other computer equipment.

ECHOboom is a place that starts conversations, connects people and engages audiences.  ECHOboom invites everyone to  experience the multidimensional complexity that exists within a Black community that is a microcosm of Black America.

We ask that you help us reach and even exceed our $120,000 goal…If we receive more…we can do more.

Features on the ECHOboom Platform

CHIME-IN : Community Conversations

  • Chime-In provokes conversation through compelling blog posts.

BOOM - News & Information

  • Boom is the news and information section on ECHOboom presenting current or trending topics. This section also conveys Tuskegee University campus life and alumni stories. With our strategic partnership with a student-operated campus radio station, we offer live streaming content.

BRAVO - Celebrating Our Best

  • Bravo is where we highlight our hometown heroes and  community projects. 

LIFT - Business Growth and Sustainment

  • Lift is our way of helping local businesses grow and prosper. In other words, we are using our resources to "uplift" entrepreneurs in the community. 

PASSPORT - Tourist Assets

  • Passport helps visitors navigate the Tuskegee tourism experience by serving as a one-stop shopping resource regarding places to go and things to do.

CALENDAR - Community Calendar of Events

  • The community calendar  tells people what's going on in Tuskegee and also empowers them to upload their own events and activities for inclusion on the community calendar. 

Tuskegee Rising

ECHOboom is keeping a close watch on the plans, projects and people involved with transforming Tuskegee into a vibrant community.  We call this "Tuskegee Rising" and we created this artwork to symbolize the dawning of a new day.

                               

We imprinted the image on t-shirts, which you can purchase as a perk to support  our crowdfunding campaign.

Remember..."The Renaissance Starts With Us"

Founders

ECHOboom is a partnership between two kindred spirits – Jazlyn Fuller and Karin Hopkins.

Jazlyn graduated from Tuskegee University in 2015.  Even though she lived in New York briefly and worked at a white advertising agency, she felt a calling that was bigger than fat paychecks and job promotions.

Originally from Los Angeles, she has observed struggling black communities on the West Coast, East Coast and Deep South. The struggle does not deter her instead it motivates her to fight for change. This is why she returned to Tuskegee, where jobs are limited to a few dollar stores and fast food restaurants. She is a disciple of the Booker T. Washington “Cast down your bucket where you are”  empowerment gospel. Jazlyn interpreted this famous saying to mean use the resources you have to get to the next level.

Fate connected Jazlyn to Karin Hopkins, a Tuskegee resident who is a veteran communications professional and seasoned entrepreneur. 

Like most people today, Karin uses computer technology to access news and and other content. An award-winning documentary producer,  former television news anchor, successful business owner and corporate communications executive, Karin's career encompasses traditional media and digital media.  Perplexed about why  Tuskegee had such a spotty presence in the digital media space, her entrepreneurial instincts kicked in.  She approached Jazlyn and proposed a partnership, which evolved into ECHOboom. They launched in September 2016 and also began raising money to sustain their vision.

The goal is $120,000 for a first-phase growth plan.
    
Writer/Editor                                            $20,000
Graphic Designer                                     $20,000
IT Specialist                                               $20,000
Still Photographer                                   $20,000
Video Photographer                               $20,000
Legal Filings & Services                         $  4,000    
App Design & Development                 $  8,000
Marketing & Promotions                       $  8,000

Each contribution is an investment in a historically significant African-American community.

    PLEASE DONATE...ANY AMOUNT $5, $50, $100 OR MORE

    ALSO ENCOURAGE OTHERS TO SUPPORT ECHOBOOM

    Financial contributions are the lifeblood of this enterprise.

    Contributions allow us to create jobs and rekindle hope in a city that desperately needs both.
        
    Historical Perspective

    African-American media first began with newspapers targeting this consumer market. Print media pioneers, Samuel Cornish and John Brown Russwurm published the Freedom's Journal in 1827. 

    During the antebellum South, other African-American newspapers emerged, including The North Star founded by Frederick Douglass. As African-Americans migrated to other areas of the country, virtually every large city with a significant African-American population had newspapers that addressed African-American issues and concerns. 

    The black press served a vital role as black people began demanding equal rights, efforts that eventually swelled into the Civil Rights Movement. The black press kept black America informed during this critical time. 

    They covered demonstrations, riots, and speeches by leaders such as Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. but for the first time, the black press was not alone in covering events that meant something to African-Americans. The Civil Rights Movement was a national news story and white-owned media could not ignore it. After decades of being overlooked and disrespected, news of the struggles of black men and women appeared in the pages of mainstream newspapers and magazines and was also reported on television newscasts controlled by national news networks.

    Black radio was also in the media mix during the Civil Rights Movement. Serving as a message board, urban radio stations transmitted vital information about strategies, meetings and marches. As white listeners began tuning in to hear the Motown sound and other black music, the audience diversified.  Through black radio whites learned more about black culture, chipping away at racial prejudices.

    In the tradition of the advocacy press, ECHOboom is an African-American media service for the 21st century. There is still a need for presentation of African-American news, opinions and perspectives.

    Tuskegee is 98% African-American community that is  experiencing  issues comparable to other predominantly black cities and towns.

    Through ECHOboom and other progressive ventures, Tuskegee can once again serve as a hub for innovation. As this new history is being written, ECHOboom will be recorded as a first for Tuskegee - an echo of  our legendary past, sparking a technology boom involving digital media communications.

    ECHOboom is in synch with Tuskegee Rising.
story_txt:
WE ECHO TO BOOMWe chose our name to honor our history. We are an "ECHO" of the days when Tuskegee thrived. Connecting the past and present, we added "boom" since our platform is a place where conversations explode. ECHOboom is a multi-media platform featuring blogs, news, opinions, videos, community calendar, community business directory, tourism resources, Tuskegee University student innovators, alumni success stories and a university marketplace populated by student and alumni business enterprises. ECHboom is accessible 24/7 on your smart phone, iPad and other computer equipment.ECHOboom is a place that starts conversations, connects people and engages audiences.  ECHOboom invites everyone to  experience the multidimensional complexity that exists within a Black community that is a microcosm of Black America.We ask that you help us reach and even exceed our $120,000 goal…If we receive more…we can do more.Features on the ECHOboom PlatformCHIME-IN : Community ConversationsChime-In provokes conversation through compelling blog posts.BOOM - News & InformationBoom is the news and information section on ECHOboom presenting current or trending topics. This section also conveys Tuskegee University campus life and alumni stories. With our strategic partnership with a student-operated campus radio station, we offer live streaming content.BRAVO - Celebrating Our BestBravo is where we highlight our hometown heroes and  community projects. LIFT - Business Growth and SustainmentLift is our way of helping local businesses grow and prosper. In other words, we are using our resources to "uplift" entrepreneurs in the community. PASSPORT - Tourist AssetsPassport helps visitors navigate the Tuskegee tourism experience by serving as a one-stop shopping resource regarding places to go and things to do.CALENDAR - Community Calendar of EventsThe community calendar  tells people what's going on in Tuskegee and also empowers them to upload their own events and activities for inclusion on the community calendar. 
Tuskegee RisingECHOboom is keeping a close watch on the plans, projects and people involved with transforming Tuskegee into a vibrant community.  We call this "Tuskegee Rising" and we created this artwork to symbolize the dawning of a new day.                               We imprinted the image on t-shirts, which you can purchase as a perk to support  our crowdfunding campaign.Remember..."The Renaissance Starts With Us"FoundersECHOboom is a partnership between two kindred spirits – Jazlyn Fuller and Karin Hopkins.Jazlyn graduated from Tuskegee University in 2015.  Even though she lived in New York briefly and worked at a white advertising agency, she felt a calling that was bigger than fat paychecks and job promotions.Originally from Los Angeles, she has observed struggling black communities on the West Coast, East Coast and Deep South. The struggle does not deter her instead it motivates her to fight for change. This is why she returned to Tuskegee, where jobs are limited to a few dollar stores and fast food restaurants. She is a disciple of the Booker T. Washington “Cast down your bucket where you are”  empowerment gospel. Jazlyn interpreted this famous saying to mean use the resources you have to get to the next level.Fate connected Jazlyn to Karin Hopkins, a Tuskegee resident who is a veteran communications professional and seasoned entrepreneur. Like most people today, Karin uses computer technology to access news and and other content. An award-winning documentary producer,  former television news anchor, successful business owner and corporate communications executive, Karin's career encompasses traditional media and digital media.  Perplexed about why  Tuskegee had such a spotty presence in the digital media space, her entrepreneurial instincts kicked in.  She approached Jazlyn and proposed a partnership, which evolved into ECHOboom. They launched in September 2016 and also began raising money to sustain their vision.The goal is $120,000 for a first-phase growth plan.    Writer/Editor                                            $20,000Graphic Designer                                     $20,000IT Specialist                                               $20,000Still Photographer                                   $20,000Video Photographer                               $20,000Legal Filings & Services                         $  4,000    App Design & Development                 $  8,000Marketing & Promotions                       $  8,000Each contribution is an investment in a historically significant African-American community.PLEASE DONATE...ANY AMOUNT $5, $50, $100 OR MOREALSO ENCOURAGE OTHERS TO SUPPORT ECHOBOOMFinancial contributions are the lifeblood of this enterprise.Contributions allow us to create jobs and rekindle hope in a city that desperately needs both.    Historical PerspectiveAfrican-American media first began with newspapers targeting this consumer market. Print media pioneers, Samuel Cornish and John Brown Russwurm published the Freedom's Journal in 1827. During the antebellum South, other African-American newspapers emerged, including The North Star founded by Frederick Douglass. As African-Americans migrated to other areas of the country, virtually every large city with a significant African-American population had newspapers that addressed African-American issues and concerns. The black press served a vital role as black people began demanding equal rights, efforts that eventually swelled into the Civil Rights Movement. The black press kept black America informed during this critical time. They covered demonstrations, riots, and speeches by leaders such as Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. but for the first time, the black press was not alone in covering events that meant something to African-Americans. The Civil Rights Movement was a national news story and white-owned media could not ignore it. After decades of being overlooked and disrespected, news of the struggles of black men and women appeared in the pages of mainstream newspapers and magazines and was also reported on television newscasts controlled by national news networks.Black radio was also in the media mix during the Civil Rights Movement. Serving as a message board, urban radio stations transmitted vital information about strategies, meetings and marches. As white listeners began tuning in to hear the Motown sound and other black music, the audience diversified.  Through black radio whites learned more about black culture, chipping away at racial prejudices.In the tradition of the advocacy press, ECHOboom is an African-American media service for the 21st century. There is still a need for presentation of African-American news, opinions and perspectives.Tuskegee is 98% African-American community that is  experiencing  issues comparable to other predominantly black cities and towns. Through ECHOboom and other progressive ventures, Tuskegee can once again serve as a hub for innovation. As this new history is being written, ECHOboom will be recorded as a first for Tuskegee - an echo of  our legendary past, sparking a technology boom involving digital media communications.ECHOboom is in synch with Tuskegee Rising.

story:
Short Summary

Hey Guys I'm Jamal Smith I'm the owner of VVCRadio.com based out of Baltimore City. We've been around 9 years & have tripled in size in less than 6 months! It's a wonderful growth but like all children costs of growth can get out of control. Our overhead cost has risen more than double and we want to be able to maintain that growth, while providing great services!! So we are reaching out to artists, fans & businesses. This fundraiser will conclude on Oct. 1, 2016 during our 5th annual 24hr live broadcast!! We want to have our fundraiser fully funded by that day!! 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising

$5,000.00 

Why? Good question:

1) We want repair our app!! We have some bugs that need to be worked out so everyone can enjoy Live Stream video!

2) We want to add the ability to call out of the studio to people! 

3) We need new back drops for events

4) We've been invited to all the major festivals locally & nationally, but we don't have camera equipment to properly cover the events. (Camera, mic's, cables, mic flags, stands etc..)

5) Studio A needs a better mixer & equipment for a more crisp sound. 

6) We have purchases we can't make till we settle with some creditors.

7) We must redo the entire the VVCRadio.com & Hot410.com websites

8) We need to do S.E.O. (search engine optimization) for both sites

9) We need a new PC for studio B to do better broadcasts!!

The Impact

We've been operating this station for 9 years with no investment capital except the cash from my friends & I's pockets. I work for the station full time now, so I can't fix financial problems like I use to when I was working. My closet friends are all married or have children so they can't help like they use too. So we are reaching out to you guys to help us continue to impact Baltimore & create awesome content for the fans!!!

How do your dollars effect everything:

1) You keep the hope's & Dreams of hundreds of supports of this station alive!!

2) We will finally be able to have all smart devices enjoy live video from the studio & soon from our live events!!

3) Thousands of artists from all over will continue to be supported & pushed by our dedicated staff. 

4) We can continue to be the bridge to major labels & platforms.

5) We will be able to bridge the gaps between D.C., Atlanta, Philly & P.A.

6) We will be able to finally roll out weekly video shows for your enjoyment!!

 

Risks & Challenges

For many many years VVCRadio.com was not making enough money to pay any of it's bills. We have been under staffed for our entire existence. After I took a long hard look at how other stations have structured their platforms. We began to adjust to become more effective & financially sound. Within 6 months we've become more stable than ever before! But we aren't out of the woods yet. We are looking at another 6 months to a year before we are fully financially stable. We need to make these changes to increase site activity, search engine visibility & ease of use for the casual user. Our app needs to be fully functional to attract the desired user base. Lastly we want to make sure we are broadcasting the best product on the web with crisp sound & great music!! We can definitely do this!! We are adding new shows every month, working with artists & labels all over the country & are building fresh new aggressive fan base that will help carry us into the future!! 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

We know it's hard out there for everyone (Were doing a Fundraiser)! So if your dollars are tight and you still want to help we have tons of ways you can help!!

1) Follow Us On Social Media: @vvcradio on Instagram, Twitter, Facebook & Everything Else

2) Log onto VVCRadio.com sign up for a free account and enjoy all the content we create everyday. Leave comments, post pictures, videos and ideas. Become apart of our community!!

3) Repost, retweet and spread the word about vvcradio to your friends, family & artists you know!!

4) Tell us how you feel about our content!! Be Honest!

 

We appreciate you visiting our page & Our site!! We hope you will join us in our journey to become a worldwide home for all independent artists whom are trying to find a special place to connect with new fans!!

We appreciate you visiting our page & Our site!! We hope you will join us in our journey to become a worldwide home for all independent artists whom are trying to find a special place to connect with new fans!!

story:
The Story

We are Bryan and Pat, two documentary filmmakers with a passion for storytelling.

We're riding our bikes across the United States to have a bonding experience as brothers and to tell the story of our journey.

We recently started a blog called Live High which is all about following your passion, doing what you love and going on adventures-- this is the theme for our journey and the platform we will use to vlog along the way.

We also both share a passion for inspiring youth and have connected with a 2nd and 4th grade class who will be tracking us on our journey and Skyping with us as we go.

Our plan is to document both our journey, and the stories of the people we meet along the way. We will also be vlogging the behind the scenes of making a film while on the road.

This journey is all about adventure, sharing stories and spreading love and inspiration. 

What We Need

Our goal is to raise $10,000.

We really want to use this journey as an opportunity to not only make a film, but to give back to our local community. We paired up with the Boys & Girls Club of Marshfield and will be donating half of everything we raise as scholarships for families that cannot afford the fees to the club.

Between film and cycling equipment, we have already spent over $8,000 out of pocket for this trip and will not have any income for the three months we are on the road. The funds we raise will go to offsetting some of these costs as well.

The Impact

If we are able to raise our goal, we will be able to support at least 12 families to send their kids to the Boys & Girls Club.

This will also help us with the immediate costs of the trip and producing our content.

Our main focus is spreading the message of Live High and inspiring kids and anyone else who follows our journey to follow their hearts.

By contributing, you will be helping us share this message.

Challenges

The biggest challenge we face is making a film while on the road and doing so on a really small budget. At the very bare minimum, we will be releasing a polished vlog/web series that documents the journey and will also be updating daily on Snapchat.

Can't Contribute?

Even if you can't afford to contribute, you can still help spread our message.

If you follow along on social media and share our posts and updates, you will help promote the message of following your passion, spreading love and sharing stories.

Follow Along!

Facebook

Snapchat

Instagram

YouTube

story:
Maram Jaberi and Talal Mahmood are not only filmmakers but passionate individuals who care about content and story telling. And what is more realistic than conveying stories that hit close to home? We say: nothing really. 

Inspired by one of Hip Hop’s most ingenious and popular songs of the 90s, our latest collaboration aims to rejuvenate that priceless era with a fun and light hearted approach. We aim to shed some light onto Middle Eastern pop culture and its’ ideologies of the West and to shatter the portrayal of media.  Most importantly, we will take a stance on feminism, and more specifically the Arab woman; her bravery, her coolness, her normalcy, her existing freedoms. 

Our highly relatable protagonist will drive the story and take us through her day which, no spoilers intended, is a great day. It is through her that we realise that the East and West are only separated by the distance between them.

As filmmakers, Maram and Talal have worked on various projects including a documentary about the first ever Women’s Football League in the Kingdom of Bahrain. Their strong stance on the role of women in the world plays a pivotal role in attracting audiences and creating movements of change in their region. Having worked with such themes, they are familiar with the hurdles they may face; scrutiny from society but also their appraise for making such bold statements. It is by developing subtle and powerful messages in a creative and witty way that they are able to overcome these obstacles. They understand the importance of controversy, because they know that all significant stories are almost always contestable. 

We have come to Indiegogo because we value and appreciate the way it helps creatives like us. We understand that it takes an accumulative effort in order to bring a vision to life. The funding that we require for our four minute music video is mainly going into post production and distribution as we have extensive plans to reach out to as many appropriate film festivals and online platforms as possible. Besides financial help, we also require to spread the word: something hilarious, yet so real, is coming!

story:
Hey, I'm Natalie!

 

I'm a 23 year old photojournalist. There's a reason I chose to learn photography. It became my purpose to give back to the world with the power of my camera lens and my pen.

It is my mission to raise awareness for people all over the world. Everyone deserves to share their story. They just a need a vehicle to do so. This is where my photography/writing comes in.

In March of 2017 I will be traveling to Nepal on my very first mission as a photojournalist. I'm excited, nervous, anxious, and... ready to contribute and make my mark on the world!

This will be the first of many different missions around the world. I will be visiting the women of the Bo M Karlsson Foundation, a charity dedicated to lifting the barriers that prevent women from achieving their highest potential. They have awarded many women scholarships to go to a college/trade school and use their newfound skills to give back in their own community (an opportunity they wouldn't have otherwise).

I'm so humbled to have found this opportunity. And I'm committed to sharing these faces  with the rest of world.

How exactly will I do this? I will be self-publishing a polished photography book full of powerful portraits and written stories about these women.

I believe this book will raise awareness for not only these women, but women all over the world seeking better opportunities.

This is where I need your help. 

 

What I Need & What You Get

The goal for this campaign is $7,500 which will go directly to two things:

  • A percentage toward food, shelter, etc. on my journey through Nepal.
  • The rest of the funds will go directly toward my self-published photography book.
  • 10% of ALL contributions toward this campaign will go directly to the Bo M. Karlsson Foundation.

  

 

The Impact

Your contributions will play a major role in supporting me on my first project as a photojournalist. 

More importantly, they will raise awareness for the Nepalese women seeking support on their own educational pursuits. In turn, awareness for underprivileged women all over the world will be raised.

Lastly, they will help spread the word about the Bo M. Karlsson Foundation and all of the beautiful things they are doing to support these women (feel free to click this link and learn more about what they do: http://bomkarlsson.com/about/). Again, 10% of all donations will go directly to this charity.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, and that's okay. I get it. Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Ask friends and family to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Share this campaign on social media.
  • And if you feel a call toward supporting this charity like I do, look them up and see if there are any other ways you can help (volunteering, becoming a sponser, etc.)

 

I'm sincerely grateful to everyone who is able to help me on this journey. Thank you from the bottom of my heart.

Let's raise awareness for these women together!

story:
A QUESTION OF SURVIVAL: the Story of Three Bulgarian Jews and the Holocaust 

 

                                                         Documentary film by Elka Nikolova

 

Holocaust stories have been told in dozens of films, both documentaries and features. While several have examined how Denmark rescued most of its Jews, few have touched on the complex story of my native country, Bulgaria. The short version: After enacting harsh anti-Semitic legislation in 1941-1942, in March 1943 the Bulgarian government, an ally to Germany, rounded up and handed over to Nazi Germany 11,343 Jews from Macedonia and Northern Greece, territories it occupied during the war. They all perished at Treblinka. The 48,000 Bulgarian Jews were next. After public outcry from a handful of prominent politicians, and of the Orthodox Church hierarchy, and some citizens in March 1943 the government called off the deportation of the Bulgarian Jews, thus sparing their lives. After the war, many Bulgarian Jews emigrated to Palestine, then en masse to Israel. Some of those who eventually settled in the U.S. have struggled to determine where their experiences fit into the common narrative of the Holocaust. .Are they survivors, even though they weren’t sent to concentration camps?  "A Question of Survival” explores that controversial question.

                                      With Misha, Robert, and Chaim during filming of their meeting 


WHY AM I MAKING THIS FILM?

I learned about this part of my country’s history after I arrived in New York City in 1994 and later met a few Bulgarian Jews here. Growing up in Bulgaria during the communist period, I heard very little discussion about it--maybe a paragraph or two in our history textbooks. I found the story fascinating but I was also puzzled as to why so few people in America knew anything about it. When I started discussing it with survivors, historians, public figures, and regular people, I was struck by the confusion of what they knew, and how they actually talked about it.

I met Misha Avramoff, Robert Bakish, and Chaim Zemach in New York in 2009, and knew that I had to capture their stories while they were still alive. I began shooting interviews with them. They had all lived through the war in Bulgaria as children aged 5-17, and emigrated to America with their families in the 1940s and 50s.  All were affected by their unusual survival, the realization in hindsight of how close they came to death. Each has struggled to make sense of his own story.

There are many different interpretations of why the Bulgarian Jews escaped extermination by the Nazis. Opinions depend upon political affiliation. It is true that during the war the Bulgarian government treated Jews as second class citizens: they were forced to wear small yellow stars and forbidden to operate their own businesses, their property was expropriated, Jewish men were sent to labor camps, and in May 1943 the Sofia Jews were dispersed in the provinces. And yet the particular political circumstances and sparks of tolerant empathy made it possible for a small segment of the public to pressure the government to first postpone, and later on to cancel the scheduled deportation of Bulgarian Jews to the death camps in 1943. That act of courage - of a small but vocal coalition of Bulgarians - inspired me to tell this story.  

On the other hand the story remains extremely politicized and controversial.  While the Bulgarian government spared its own country’s Jews, it handed over to Nazi Germany 11,343 Jews from Macedonia and Northern Greece, who all perished. The incongruity left both Jewish and Christian Bulgarians to struggle with conflicting feelings of pride and shame. 

Until 1989 Bulgaria remained closed off behind the Iron Curtain, access to its archives was constrained, and there was no freedom for intellectual debates. Only after the fall of the communist regime was access finally allowed, and competing narratives of the Holocaust emerged. The survival of the 48,000 Bulgarian Jews did not always fit comfortably into the already existing Holocaust narratives. It also posed uneasy questions, such as: What was the role of public resistance in saving the Jewish population? Why didn't similar resistance happen in other countries? How could the Bulgarian people hand off one population of Jews to be slaughtered, while protecting their own? As a result this story remains little known, its tremendous value lost in controversy and confusion. 

My documentary aims to shine light on the relevance of this chapter in history to our current political climate, where minorities are scapegoated for political gain, and where the role of public opinion in protecting them is ever more critical. An important part of this documentary is the larger immigrant story, and the refuge the families of Misha Avfamoff, Robert Bakish, Chaim Zemach, as well as myself, were able to find in America. 

 

                                                                    ABOUT THE FILM

My search to make meaning of history is at the center of this film. Though the events of this story happened more than 75 years ago, I can identify with Misha, Robert, and Chaim’s struggle to find a sense of belonging and meaning in their experiences. As an immigrant myself I understand their longing for a sense of home and the hardship that leaving your country behind  brings to a family. The world I grew up in changed forever in 1989, when the fall of the Berlin Wall spread regime change across Eastern Europe. As an immigrant I understand what it means to pick up the pieces and try to rebuild your life in a new place. 

As a filmmaker it made the most sense to me to tell this story using this medium. This film is not a historical documentary: its goal is not to retell in detail the historical events of 1943 or to convey conceptual interpretations.  Rather, I aim to explore the aftermath of the cancelled deportation of Bulgaria’s Jews and the effects that it had on the lives of three men from Bulgaria. Since Misha, Chaim and Robert were children at the time, they saw the world around them as a less threatening place. This enabled Chaim to think about going away as an adventure, or Misha to remember the beautiful suitcases his mother bought, or Robert to recall going skiing when his family was resettled. The adults, of course, sensed the danger, and tried desperately to shield their children from it. This is a film about asking the questions that arise from this confusion and trying to make sense of it. This is also a film that asks: where does the Bulgarian story belong in the overall narrative of the Holocaust? Can we see its value? Why does it make us uncomfortable? 

                                                  Misha visiting Hilda Weitman, a Polish survivor

 

WHERE IS THE FILMMAKING PROCESS NOW?

Filming is complete. We are seeking $25,000 to fund the post-production phase. Two-thirds of that will go toward editing, and one-third toward sound and color grading, purchasing archival footage, and music rights. With your generous contribution, we will be able to complete the final editing and bring this film to the finish line. Making a film requires teamwork. We invite you, the viewer, to become part of the making of this important story.  

 

WHY SHOULD YOU CONTRIBUTE?

Despite the fact that we are so far removed from the events of 1943, I feel deeply connected to them. My hope is that you will connect to this story in a similar way, and it will speak to you on a personal level. Because no matter how different someone's experiences are, we can find a way to connect to them. We all have known a survivor, an immigrant, or a child that needs our help and understanding. This connection with people can make a difference in moments when they most need it, when their life depends on it. This is what the Bulgarian story teaches us. It was not that no Bulgarians were antisemitic--but there were enough people who saw a neighbor or a friend whose life was being threatened, and took action that made a difference. I invite you to be that person by contributing to this project and helping to bring this story to others. 

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Time is the essence--unfortunately Robert Bakish passed away in 2019, and was not able to see the finished film. We’d love to complete the film as soon as possible so Misha and Chaim as well as Robert's family can attend the premiere. It’s important for us to be able to thank them in public for their stories, and their courage to speak openly about their struggles. Without them, this piece of history would be lost forever. 

 

TEAM

Elka Nikolova, Director/Producer/Editor

               

Elka Nikolova was born in Bulgaria and studied psychology at the University of Sofia before she moved to the United States in 1994. In 2000 she received her MA in Media Studies, with a focus on film production, at the New School in New York. She has worked in film and television in New York since 2003. Her first documentary film, "Binka: To Tell a Story About Silence," completed in 2007, premiered at MOMA in New York.  "A Question of Survival" is her second documentary film. 

Vanyo Georgiev, Cinematographer/Producer   

Vanyo Georgiev was born in Bulgaria and graduated from the New Bulgarian University in Sofia with a BA in film and television production.  He worked as a cinematographer for Bulgarian Documentary Studio "Vreme" and the TV series "8 & 1/2," produced by Film Studio Boyana, before moving to New York in 2006. In New York he works as a freelance DP and Lighting Director for Bank of America Video and Broadcast, and on various documentary productions. 

Ben Wolf, Additional Camera

Ben Wolf’s work as a cinematographer on documentary ﬁlms ranges from Emmy winner “Baring It All” (Dir: Patricia Zagarella) to “Deceptive Practice: The Mysteries and Mentors of Ricky Jay” (Dir: Molly Bernstein & Alan Edelstein), a Kino Lorber release, as well as “Amsterdam Stories USA” (Dirs: Rob Rombout & Rogier van Eck), a 6-hour road movie of small town America. He helped develop and shoot a web series for The Indian National Congress Party entitled “Billion and One Voices," a collage of modern India.

Lora  Myers, Consulting Writer/Mentor       

Lora Myers is a writer, film producer, and educator. As a producer and writer, she has worked in the USA, Italy, and Brazil on numerous award winning documentaries, public television specials, and feature film scripts. She is currently developing a song-based app for teaching English literacy.

Joseph Benatov, Historical Consultant

Joseph Benatov is Lecturer in Foreign Languages in the Modern Hebrew Language Program at the University of Pennsylvania. He holds a doctorate in Comparative Literature and Literary Theory from the University of Pennsylvania. His dissertation is titled “Looking in the Iron Mirror: Eastern Europe in the American Imaginary, 1958-2001."

Ivanka Gezenko, Archives Specialist, Project Advisor

.                                                                                                                     

Ivanka Gezenko is an archivist specializing in the archives on the Bulgarian Jewish community, and is a curator of the website http://archives.bg/jews/of Bulgaria Archives State Agency.

 

THANK YOU!!!

We are so grateful for your contribution! If a financial donation is not possible for you right now, would you consider helping in another way? Share our campaign with anyone you know who is interested in this topic or has the financial means to support us. We appreciate every share. The Indiegogo share tools can help with this. 

Follow us on FB: https://www.facebook.com/A-Question-of-Survival...

IG: https://www.instagram.com/nikol_elka/

Twitter: https://twitter.com/nikolova_elka

PayPal: https://www.paypal.me/elkageorgieva1?locale.x=e...
story_txt: A QUESTION OF SURVIVAL: the Story of Three Bulgarian Jews and the Holocaust                                                           Documentary film by Elka Nikolova Holocaust stories have been told in dozens of films, both documentaries and features. While several have examined how Denmark rescued most of its Jews, few have touched on the complex story of my native country, Bulgaria. The short version: After enacting harsh anti-Semitic legislation in 1941-1942, in March 1943 the Bulgarian government, an ally to Germany, rounded up and handed over to Nazi Germany 11,343 Jews from Macedonia and Northern Greece, territories it occupied during the war. They all perished at Treblinka. The 48,000 Bulgarian Jews were next. After public outcry from a handful of prominent politicians, and of the Orthodox Church hierarchy, and some citizens in March 1943 the government called off the deportation of the Bulgarian Jews, thus sparing their lives. After the war, many Bulgarian Jews emigrated to Palestine, then en masse to Israel. story:
Short Summary

With the success of our first campaign to produce the film short The Coward: The Movie. Thanks to all the support we received through donations, social media posts, and word-of-mouth. We are now asking for your help in our next project The Coward 2020 a feature length film. Dean Pyles is (Mark Stone), an Ex-Special Forces Soldier that moves back to his hometown, when his past comes back to haunt him over a promise he made to his dad. Severely injuring a boy using the Martial Arts training he had received his whole life, puts Mark, his family, and friends in the path of a group of bullies, that will stop at nothing to get at Mark, even terrorizing the entire town. What is holding Mark to his promise? Will he put together the pieces and STOP THE BULLYING? Or will he let it go and let everyone suffer, including himself, remaining “The Coward”?

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising money for a feature length film to follow-up on our short film. To continue our mission to Stop Bullying and to bring awareness to the world about Dean Pyles, his family, Team PVT, and the Guardian Angels’ efforts to put a stop to bullying. 

Pledge Promises and Amounts:

$1.00 Pledge – The knowledge you personally helped a worthwhile cause. (1,000)

$5.00 Pledge – The knowledge you personally helped a worthwhile cause. (1,000)

$10.00 Pledge – An e-mail from Dean Pyles personally thanking you. (1,000)

$25.00 Pledge – An e-mail from Dean Pyles personally thanking you & a printable digital image of Dean Pyles. (1,000)

$50.00 Pledge - An e-mail from Dean Pyles personally thanking you, a printable digital image of Dean Pyles, and a digital group picture of the cast. (1,000)

$100.00 Pledge – An e-mail from Dean Pyles personally thanking you, a printable digital image of Dean Pyles, and a digital group picture of the cast.  Plus: A Letter from Dean sent via USPS (1,000)

$250.00 Pledge – An e-mail from Dean Pyles personally thanking you, a printable digital image of Dean Pyles, and a digital group picture of the cast.  Plus: A Letter from Dean sent.00 via USPS and official DPK. (1,000)

$500 Pledge – An e-mail from Dean Pyles personally thanking you, a printable digital image of Dean Pyles, and a digital group picture of the cast.  Plus: A Letter from Dean sent.00 via USPS, and an official DPK including selected music from the film. (1,000)

$1,000 Pledge – – An e-mail from Dean Pyles personally thanking you, a printable digital image of Dean Pyles, and a digital group picture of the cast.  Plus: A Letter from Dean sent.00 via USPS, an official DPK including selected music from the film, a copy of The Coward Home for the Holidays, a credit at our IMDB page, and our website. (10)

$5,000 Pledge – – An e-mail from Dean Pyles personally thanking you, a printable digital image of Dean Pyles, and a digital group picture of the cast.  Plus: A Letter from Dean sent.00 via USPS, an official DPK including selected music from the film, a copy of The Coward Home for the Holidays, a credit at our IMDB page, a credit on our website, and listing in the film credits. (1)

The Impact

Dean Pyles a Living Legend, Hall of Fame, World Champion Martial Artist wants to help put an end to BULLYING by raising awareness of far reaching effects bullying has on not only on those who are being bullied but the bullies themselves. Bullying is something that affects people of all ages both old and young alike.

Risks & Challenges

Dean Pyles is a 4th generation Marine who proudly served his country in times of peace and in times of war. He still works with the US Military Special Forces and Law Enforcement Agencies.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to donate, please reach out and let us know as there are many ways to help without donating money.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary

CLOWNS IN THE WOODS is an independent horror movie with creepy villains, twisted kills, and a spooky small-town atmosphere.

In the tradition of CANDYMAN and NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET, this will be a horror movie about the sins of the past, as a younger generation must grapple with the consequences of past injustice.

We have been fans of horror films since a young age, especially independent regional horror films. We want to create a horror movie which is inspired by the 2016 clown sightings, and to incorporate and include people with disabilities in both the story and the production.

Since our co-director Adrian Esposito is on the Autism spectrum, we feel this film is important because it has the potential to break the mold of how people with disabilities are seen.

Our film has a prominent lead role for an actor with a disability. This character, Marcus, is a young man who is bullied in the community and dies when a vicious prank goes wrong. He then comes back from the grave as a killer clown, to enact revenge on those who have wronged him. He enacts his revenge with the help of other killer clowns, who have their own slapstick methods of causing death and destruction.

One of Marcus’s few friends in life was his neighbor Amy, a lesbian college student. As the deaths pile up, Amy is determined to learn the deadly secret behind the recent wave of murders, little realizing that she may be putting herself and her loved ones in danger.

The Impact

Many people are prejudiced against low-budget horror movies. We want to change this by including people with disabilities in them. We also want to show that there is value in horror genre storytelling, by diving into the worlds of make-believe and dark fantasy, and by having characters get their just desserts that they would escape from in real life.

We hope that you will help us achieve our goal of making this innovative and timely horror movie a reality.

The Team

We have a long history of independent filmmaking.

Co-director Adrian Esposito’s credits include producing and writing a narrative film called Bury My Heart With Tonawanda. He has also directed several feature length documentaries including Greetings from Tromaville, about Lloyd Kaufman and Troma Entertainment, and Diffability Hollywood, about the history of people with disabilities in films. More of his credits can be viewed here:  https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3982944/

Co-director Curt Markham has been making films since he was a teenager. “Saberfrog,” “Curse the Darkness” and “The Search for Silverspear.” He was an in-house videographer and usability engineer at Xerox Corporation and has written industrial films for Eastman Kodak Corp. At Rochester’s PBS station WXXI-TV, he was a segment producer for “Homework Hotline” and “Assignment: The World” and directed episodes of the talk show “Sound Bytes.” He co-starred in the web series “The Whitemeats” and wrote and acted in the award-winning horror comedy short “Enter the Dagon.” More of his credits can be viewed here:  https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3783013

Executive producer Kristina Nomeika is Adrian Esposito's production partner, producing over 12 years of documentary and feature productions for Espocinema. These include the award-winning Diffability Hollywood, Inner Healing, We Can Shine, and many others.

Dalton Letta who will star in the lead role of Marcus in Clowns in the Woods is a known spokesperson and “ambassador” for autism in the Rochester NY area. He is one of the founders of Campaign D, an organization whose mission is to bring awareness of autism and the abilities of those on the autism spectrum. He is the Monroe County “Face of Autism Advocate” and advocate for autism in the Town of Gates as well as with NY State Legislators: Senator Joe Robach and Frank Allkofer. We discovered Dalton when he starred as Shrek in Shrek The Musical in the recent Artists Unlimited production here in Rochester NY.  His performance was so excellent, so professional that we approached him right after the performance to offer him a role in Clowns in the Woods. Dalton has starred in many other local productions just to mention a few: he was Captain Hook in Peter Pan, King Maximillian in Cinderella, Robertson Aye the butler in Many Poppins, Chef Louie in The Little Mermaid, Augustus Gloop in Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. Dalton’s dream is to star in films and national theater. We hope that Dalton can achieve his goals and fulfill his dreams.

We are thrilled to have Dalton Latta on board.The production will also feature many other actors with disabilities.

 Stay tuned for more updates!

What We Need & What You Get

We have some of the seed money in place already. We are looking for additional funds to increase the resources available to the cast and crew and to be able to finish the production without any setbacks or delays.

In contributing to our campaign you will receive one or more of the following:

  • Special Thanks credit
  • Clowns in the Woods T-Shirt
  • Digital Download
  • Clowns in the Woods DVD
  • Greetings from Tromaville/Clowns in the Woods DVD/Blu-Ray Combo
  • Clowns in the Woods VHS (Limited Edition)
  • Co - Producer credit
  • Associate Producer credit

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word on Clowns in the Woods by sharing this link!
story_txt:
Short Summary
CLOWNS IN THE WOODS is an independent horror movie with creepy villains, twisted kills, and a spooky small-town atmosphere.
In the tradition of CANDYMAN and NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET, this will be a horror movie about the sins of the past, as a younger generation must grapple with the consequences of past injustice.
We have been fans of horror films since a young age, especially independent regional horror films. We want to create a horror movie which is inspired by the 2016 clown sightings, and to incorporate and include people with disabilities in both the story and the production.
Since our co-director Adrian Esposito is on the Autism spectrum, we feel this film is important because it has the potential to break the mold of how people with disabilities are seen.
Our film has a prominent lead role for an actor with a disability. This character, Marcus, is a young man who is bullied in the community and dies when a vicious prank goes wrong. He then comes back from the grave as a killer clown, to enact revenge on those who have wronged him. He enacts his revenge with the help of other killer clowns, who have their own slapstick methods of causing death and destruction.
One of Marcus’s few friends in life was his neighbor Amy, a lesbian college student. As the deaths pile up, Amy is determined to learn the deadly secret behind the recent wave of murders, little realizing that she may be putting herself and her loved ones in danger.
The Impact
Many people are prejudiced against low-budget horror movies. We want to change this by including people with disabilities in them. We also want to show that there is value in horror genre storytelling, by diving into the worlds of make-believe and dark fantasy, and by having characters get their just desserts that they would escape from in real life.
We hope that you will help us achieve our goal of making this innovative and timely horror movie a reality.
The Team
We have a long history of independent filmmaking.
Co-director Adrian Esposito’s credits include producing and writing a narrative film called Bury My Heart With Tonawanda. He has also directed several feature length documentaries including Greetings from Tromaville, about Lloyd Kaufman and Troma Entertainment, and Diffability Hollywood, about the history of people with disabilities in films. More of his credits can be viewed here:  https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3982944/
Co-director Curt Markham has been making films since he was a teenager. “Saberfrog,” “Curse the Darkness” and “The Search for Silverspear.” He was an in-house videographer and usability engineer at Xerox Corporation and has written industrial films for Eastman Kodak Corp. At Rochester’s PBS station WXXI-TV, he was a segment producer for “Homework Hotline” and “Assignment: The World” and directed episodes of the talk show “Sound Bytes.” He co-starred in the web series “The Whitemeats” and wrote and acted in the award-winning horror comedy short “Enter the Dagon.” More of his credits can be viewed here:  https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3783013


Executive producer Kristina Nomeika is Adrian Esposito's production partner, producing over 12 years of documentary and feature productions for Espocinema. These include the award-winning Diffability Hollywood, Inner Healing, We Can Shine, and many others.

Dalton Letta who will star in the lead role of Marcus in Clowns in the Woods is a known spokesperson and “ambassador” for autism in the Rochester NY area. He is one of the founders of Campaign D, an organization whose mission is to bring awareness of autism and the abilities of those on the autism spectrum. He is the Monroe County “Face of Autism Advocate” and advocate for autism in the Town of Gates as well as with NY State Legislators: Senator Joe Robach and Frank Allkofer. We discovered Dalton when he starred as Shrek in Shrek The Musical in the recent Artists Unlimited production here in Rochester NY.  His performance was so excellent, so professional that we approached him right after the performance to offer him a role in Clowns in the Woods. Dalton has starred in many other local productions just to mention a few: he was Captain Hook in Peter Pan, King Maximillian in Cinderella, Robertson Aye the butler in Many Poppins, Chef Louie in The Little Mermaid, Augustus Gloop in Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. Dalton’s dream is to star in films and national theater. We hope that Dalton can achieve his goals and fulfill his dreams.
We are thrilled to have Dalton Latta on board.The production will also feature many other actors with disabilities.
 Stay tuned for more updates!
What We Need & What You Get
We have some of the seed money in place already. We are looking for additional funds to increase the resources available to the cast and crew and to be able to finish the production without any setbacks or delays.
In contributing to our campaign you will receive one or more of the following:

Special Thanks credit
Clowns in the Woods T-Shirt
Digital Download
Clowns in the Woods DVD
Greetings from Tromaville/Clowns in the Woods DVD/Blu-Ray Combo
Clowns in the Woods VHS (Limited Edition)
